content.description:
Never has a route name been more appropriate. This is 100 feet of incredibly secure, painful jamming up a proud line that can be seen from the road. Glorious agony. 

  From the ledge, the line can't be missed. It is the left crack of the two, and continues up, leaning slightly right, past a tree growing out of the crack,  to a ledge just below the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Standard rack with doubles in hand sized pieces.
content.location:
The route starts from a ledge about 100 off the ground, where P2 of Great Northern Diver ends. The easiest way to reach it is to climb Green Mountain Boys, then a short pitch up and right from Window Box Ledge. There is a bolted anchor about 10' right of the base of the crack. 

  Gear anchor at the top, or place a directional, and walk to the bolted anchor 30' right. 3 raps with a 70m, using the Great Northern Diver stations, put you back on the ground.

content.description:
An amazing crack line, with a variety of sizes, and an awesome, burly fingers section! 

  Climb up to the ledge, and get ready to turn it on for the next 60 feet. The crack starts as off hands/fists, before pinching down to fingers and steepening up. It then opens to off width, but there is a rest possible at this section, and the offwidth is surprisingly straightforward thanks to features out right. Continue in the left crack (a bit dirty), then up over a steep bit with positive holds to a slab. Run up right to a fixed anchor on a large ledge, shared with Green Mountain Boys.
content.protection:
Emphasis on finger sized gear. A #5 is great for the bottom of the offwidth.  

  Fixed anchor on a tree.
content.location: 10' left of Green Mountain Boys, below an obvious steep splitter. There is a small ledge with a tree 12' up.

content.description: A tremendous pitch, sustained once the business gets going, and an amazing linkup with any of the cracks below it. Named for the constant water dripping from a seepage hole on the roof - the cracks' innards are usually dry, but you might have to embrace a few wet edges on the outside. From the Window Box Ledge, scramble up the ledges to the base of the arching corner crack. Punch it up and around the roof, then make a switch left into a handcrack. Climb up as it widens before reaching a ledge. A stembox with some positive, but slightly suspect, wedged blocks leads to the top.Figure out an anchor - one way or another, rappel Finger Lockn' Good to your right. Three rappels with a 70m rope (yes it is mandatory). Maybe grab a quick TR burn on Great Northern Diver on your way down!
content.protection: A pretty loaded rack. Doubles maybe from .75-3 Camalots. Some small pieces also helpful.
content.location: At the Window Box Ledge, reached via a couple different routes. The very obvious crack system above the open area of the ledge is the climb!

climbs.name: Green Mountain Boys
climbs.fa: Matt Way, Colin Loher, Jesse Littleton

content.description: Start in the overhanging corner with the jug at head heigh. Climb the corner through the bulges to a ledge. Climb the second half of the corner to a sloping ledge. On its right side is a tree with rap anchors, belay here.
content.protection: Perhaps some extra hand size gear.
content.location: Between Handlebarbarism and Great Northern Diver. Behind a small island of trees.

content.description: One of the best single pitches of trad climbing in the Adirondack Park.Up the corner to a fixed anchor... Easier said than done! A second pitch (5.6) can bring you to the fixed anchors at the base of Tales of Weakness and Finger Lockn' Good.
content.protection: Standard rack. 70m rope if doing any of the higher pitches. The fixed anchor was upgraded in 2018 - no backup piece is necessary (as indicated in Adirondack Rock)
content.location: Up the short second/third class slab to the right of the alcove of Green Mountain Boys.

climbs.name: Blueberry Buttress
climbs.fa: P2 Kevin Crowl, Adam Crofoot 2009; P1 Crowl, Julia Gronski, Micah Stewart 2010

content.description: In it's current state, I'd recommend it more as a character-building exercise, or perhaps for philosophical reasons. For instance, if you've ever pondered the question "how dirty does a route have to get before it's unclimbable?" It probably would be a very nice route with some cleaning, but alas, I forgot my wire brush, trowel, cultivator and hedge shears when I climbed it. The first pitch climbs an attractive crack, then continues up a dirt runnel that's hidden from the ground, and onto a tree belay. The little traffic this route gets seems to intelligently stop here at an aging sling.The book describes the second pitch as heading up the cracks and corners for 100' and alludes to some vegetation. Indeed, excavate a few pounds of moss and dirt, pull on cedars and junipers, jam and thrutch, then reach an easy friction finish. There are no grades for some of these things. It'd probably be best to break the second pitch up too, as I was about 130' up when I decided to stop with barely adequate gear to build a mid-pitch belay in order to bring my follower up so I could protect the finish. Top out in an other-worldly forest of pines and blueberries. Walk off to the climber's left is probably best, heading through the dreamy ecology and past the scenic true summit of the Summit Cliff.
content.protection: Summit Cliff rack (loaded in hand and finger sizes) to #4 C4. Gardening tools. Maybe add some tricams, they'll work better in the dirty cracks!
content.location: Flakes and an attractive handcrack climber's right of a tree-filled chimney slightly uphill from the toe of the cliff, around the corner to the right of Great Northern Diver

content.description: A south facing summit cliff with many high quality cracks. This area is somewhat reminiscent of the Barkeater Crag but with more difficult climbs.  The Summit Cliff has an impressive prow that is easily seen from the road. This area could use more traffic; it would clean some of the existing high quality cracks and improve the approach trail.  There is also a lot of potential for route development. A great area for crack climbers in the 5.10 range.
